_prev_prog_2.MH_OtherType: Loss of Inhibitor, Loss of Nitrogen Blanket, Polymerization in Marine Vapor Control System
_prev_prog_2.PC_OtherType: Storage in IFR Tank.  Nitrogen Blanketing System on Tank.  Automated valve on dedicated A6-D3-89 Dock Line end & Truck Rack T-4 Loading Line for Tank Q30-13.  Controlled Loading.  Overfill alarm.
_prev_prog_2.MS_OtherType: Permanent and Portable Water / Foam Delivery Systems.  Fire-Fighting Water Delivery Monitors Installed.
_prev_prog_2.MD_OtherType: Monthly inhibitor level check by third-party surveyor. Inhibitor added and the tank circulated, as necessary.  Quarterly LDAR program.  Camera network viewable in 24-hour Operations Control Room.
_prev_prog_2.CH_OtherChanges: New Covered Process for VAM Storage in Tank Q30-13 as of November 2024.
_prev_prog_2.EquipmentTested: Vapor Combustor VC-03 Weekly Preventative Maintenance Inspection (W/O 50428)

_prev_prog_3.MH_OtherType: TDI contact with moisture/water, loss of plant nitrogen supply, TDI incompatibility with other chemicals present in the common vapor system, blocked product filters, pump run-dry.
_prev_prog_3.PC_OtherType: Tank & loading overfill protection, external/mineral oil heating, N2, vapor line carbon drums, separate vapor system at R-2, conservation vent dessicant system, automated pump and valve controls.
_prev_prog_3.MD_OtherType: Quarterly leak detection and repair (LDAR) program for vapor lines. Camera network viewable in 24-hour Operations Control Room.  Tank cargo temperature monitoring.
_prev_prog_3.CH_OtherChanges: PHA Updated in June 2020 for D-Tank Farm TDI Storage.  Stored cargo changes in interconnected D-Tank Farm Tanks.  D-Tank Farm fully automated in 2021. 30,000-barrel reduction in maximum TDI inventory.
_prev_prog_3.EquipmentTested: Vapor Combustor VC-03 Weekly Preventative Maintenance Inspection (W/O 50428)

_prev_prog_3.MH_OtherType: No Nitrogen Pad in ISO Tank Container Being Loaded, improper grounding.
_prev_prog_3.PC_OtherType: Nitrogen Pad on ISO Container Prior to Loading. Automated Shut-Down of Flare System. Automated control valves added on R2-T6-70 Transfer Line. ISO Tanks loaded on scale. Overfill Protection System.
_prev_prog_3.MS_OtherType: Permanent and Portable Fire Water / Foam Delivery Systems.  Portable Fire Extinguishers.
_prev_prog_3.MD_OtherType: Quarterly leak detection and repair (LDAR) program. Camera network viewable in 24-hour Operations Control Room.
_prev_prog_3.CH_OtherChanges: Commenced Mixed Pentanes Transfers in 2020.  Previously handled Isopentane & n-Pentane separately.  Automated valves added at Truck Rack T-6 & Rail Rack R-2 on Pentanes Transfer Line (R2-T6-70).
_prev_prog_3.EquipmentTested: Routine Preventative Maintenance Inspection of the Tank Farm Vent Flare

_prev_prog_3.MH_OtherType: Loss of Inhibitor, Loss of Nitrogen Blanket, Polymerization in Marine Vapor Control System
_prev_prog_3.PC_OtherType: Stored in IFR Tanks, Nitrogen Blanketing System, Dedicated Marine Line with Automated Valve, SAAB Radar Gauges, Hermetic Gauge/Sample Systems, Vapor System Purges, Controlled Marine Loading
_prev_prog_3.MS_OtherType: Permanent and Portable Water / Foam Delivery Systems.  Fire-Fighting Water Delivery Monitors Installed South of Tank P50-5.
_prev_prog_3.MD_OtherType: Quarterly leak detection and repair (LDAR) program. Camera network viewable in 24-hour Operations Control Room. Tank level and temperature monitoring.
_prev_prog_3.CH_OtherChanges: Full automation of P-Tank Farm scheduled for a 2025 start date.
_prev_prog_3.EquipmentTested: Routine Preventative Maintenance Inspection of the Marine Vapor Combustor VC-03 (W/O 50428)

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
REASON FOR RISK MANAGEMENT PLAN RESUBMISSION AND UPDATE

Stolthaven Houston, Inc. is updating the facility's Risk Management Plan ("RMP") in November of 2024 as a result of planned changes involving additional Vinyl Acetate Monomer ("VAM") storage and handling in a new Covered Process at the Stolthaven Houston Terminal.  Since the facility's last RMP update in December of 2020, Stolthaven Houston has also significantly reduced the maximum inventory of Toluene Diisocyanate ("TDI") stored on-site, and ceased handling Acrylonitrile.    VAM, TDI, and Acrylonitrile are all regulated toxic substances under the RMP regulations.  

The specific changes associated with this RMP update include:

- Adding VAM storage in Internal Floating Roof ("IFR") Storage Tank Q30-13 above the Threshold Quantity, and associated VAM handling, in a new covered process at the Stolthaven Houston Terminal. 

- Removing a previously Covered Process from the RMP for Acrylonitrile Transfers.  Stolthaven Houston no longer handles Acrylonitrile on-site.  

- Updating the D-Tank Farm Covered Process to reflect a 30,000-barrel reduction in the maximum TDI inventory stored on-site.  TDI is no longer held in Low-Pressure Storage Tank D30-10, which previously represented the Worst-Case Release Scenario for this chemical at the Stolthaven Houston Terminal.  

- Providing a new Worst Case Release Scenario for toxics.  Previously Acrylonitrile represented the Worst Case Release Scenario for regulated toxic chemicals handled at the facility.  

- Updating facility contact information, and  

- Various data element updates since the December 2020 RMP certification.  


§ 68.155(a):  ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES

Stolthaven Houston, Inc. is committed to operating and maintaining our processes related to bulk chemical storage and distribution in a safe and responsible manner.  The facility uses a combination of accidental release prevention and emergency response planning program

s to protect the environment and to ensure the safety of our employees and assets, our industrial neighbors, and the citizens of the surrounding community.  This Executive Summary provides a brief overview of the comprehensive risk management activities that Stolthaven Houston, Inc. has designed and implemented, including:

- A description of our facility and the substances regulated by 40 CFR 68 that may be handled on-site in stationary sources above their corresponding Threshold Quantities.

- An overview of our accidental release prevention programs.

- A five-year history of significant accidental releases, if applicable, from processes covered by the United States Environmental Protection Agency ("EPA") RMP regulations.

- An overview of our emergency response programs.

- An overview of completed and planned improvements at the facility to help prevent accidental chemical releases from occurring, and

- Detailed information about our RMP.


§ 68.155(b):  STATIONARY SOURCES AND REGULATED SUBSTANCES HANDLED

Stolthaven Houston, Inc. owns and operates a bulk liquids storage and distribution terminal located on the north side of the Houston Ship Channel near Channelview in eastern Harris County, Texas.  The facility currently consists of 188 above-ground "for-hire" storage tanks that vary in capacity from 2,000-barrels up to 110,000-barrels, five truck loading/unloading racks (Truck Racks T-3, T-4, T-5, T-6, and T-8), four rail car loading/unloading racks (Rail Racks R-1, R-2, R-3, and R-5), one dedicated barge dock (Barge Dock-C), a finger pier jetty equipped with two separate marine vessel berths for handling barges and ships (Dock 2/3), and a jetty placed into service in 2019 for handling barges and ships (Dock 11).  A rail car cleaning and intermodal transfer station (Rail Rack R-4 and Truck Rack T-7) is also located within the Stolthaven Houston Terminal, and a biological waste water treatment plant and various air pollution control devices are operated on-si

te to reduce the impact of the Stolthaven Houston Terminal's operations on the environment.

Bulk liquid products are received into the Stolthaven Houston Terminal by various modes of transportation cargo container including tank trucks, ISO tank containers, flexi-bags, rail tank cars, barges, and marine parcel tankers.  The received liquid products are stored on-site according to customer-specified requirements, and are subsequently transferred off-site through one or more of the above-referenced transportation modes.  Stolthaven Houston, Inc. also performs direct product transfers between marine vessels and rail tank cars with no intermediate storage in the facility's above-ground storage tanks.  Similarly, land-based intermodal ("IMO") transfers directly between tank trucks, ISO tank containers, flexi-bags, and rail tank cars are also performed routinely at the Stolthaven Houston Terminal.  Note that Stolthaven Houston, Inc. does not perform any chemical processing or chemical manufacturing operations on-site, and the company does not own nor ultimately control the disposition of the various bulk liquid products that are stored or otherwise handled at the facility.

The following chemicals handled at Stolthaven Houston, Inc. are identified by the EPA as having the potential to cause adverse off-site consequences in the event of a significant accidental release:

Regulated Toxic Substances Currently in Storage:

Toluene Diisocyanate, Mixed Isomers: Chemical Abstracts Service ("CAS") Number 26471-62-5
Vinyl Acetate Monomer: CAS Number 108-05-4

Regulated Flammable Substances Handled via Intermodal Transfers (Rail Cars into ISO Tank Containers):

Isopentane: CAS Number 78-78-4
n-Pentane:  CAS Number 109-66-0
Pentane Blends (5-95% Isopentane and n-Pentane Mixtures)

TDI and VAM currently represent the only two RMP regulated substances at Stolthaven Houston, Inc. that are present on-site above their corresponding Threshold Quantities at all times.  Isopentane, n-Penta

ne, and Pentane Blends consisting of between 5 and 95-percent Isopentane and n-Pentane are periodically transloaded directly from rail tank cars into ISO tank containers with no intermediate on-site storage, other than loaded rail cars received into the facility that are staged on the terminal's rail storage tracks prior to performing the transfer into empty ISO Tank Containers.  Accordingly, Isopentane and n-Pentane are not always present above their respective Threshold Quantities at the Stolthaven Houston Terminal.  As such, the "Predictive Filing" option in Section 1 (Registration Information), Item 1.16, of this RMP is noted as "Y".   

Our training and accidental release prevention programs in combination with our Standard Operating Procedures ("SOP") and contingency planning efforts help us effectively manage potential hazards posed to our employees, the public, and the environment during the storage and/or transfer of the above-referenced RMP regulated substances.


TOLUENE DIISOCYANATE STORAGE AND TRANSFERS: PROCESS 1

Stolthaven Houston, Inc. currently stores TDI in two 15,000-barrel nominal capacity above-ground storage tanks (Low-Pressure Storage Tanks D15-19 and D15-22).  Tank D15-19, which represents the facility's largest volume of TDI held in a single storage vessel, has a maximum TDI storage capacity of approximately 6.3-million pounds (617,718-gallons), and Tank D15-22 has a maximum TDI storage capacity of approximately 6.2-million pounds (610,729-gallons).  TDI is received into the facility via delivery by marine parcel tankers, tank trucks, and rail tank cars; TDI is shipped outbound from Stolthaven Houston, Inc. by rail tank cars and marine parcel tankers.  Periodic direct transfers of TDI from marine vessels into rail tank cars is also performed at Stolthaven Houston, Inc. with no intermediate product storage in the two referenced D-Tank Farm low-pressure storage tanks.  Note that Stolthaven Houston, Inc. has over 30-years' experience in the sa

fe storage and handling of TDI. 

As part of the changes associated with additional TDI storage in Low-Pressure Storage Tank D15-19 (Stolthaven Houston's most recent TDI expansion project), significant modifications were performed such that TDI is handled safely and efficiently in this tank, including installing a liner on the storage tank's floor and shell, installing a pipeline constructed of 316L stainless steel from the storage tank to the existing dock line in D-Manifold used exclusively for TDI marine-based transfers, replacing all existing gate valves on the Tank D15-19 system with ball valves for ease of operation and automation capability using pneumatic actuators, installing a stainless-steel pump for TDI at Storage Tank D15-19, installing hot water external heating panels, a water tank, and associated heating panel supply/return lines for Storage Tank D15-19 while in TDI service, insulating Tank D15-19, installing internal eductors at the tank's recirculation line to improve product mixing, installing electric heat tracing and insulation on the tank's lateral pipeline to D-Manifold, installing a dehydrator on the tank's vacuum breaker to help prevent moisture from entering the vapor space should there be a loss of plant nitrogen, and installing a carbon adsorption canister on the Storage Tank D15-19 vapor line prior to TDI vapors entering the terminal's common Tank Farm Vent Flare vapor header to reduce the concentration of TDI in the vapor system.  Full automation for D-Tank Farm has been completed, which provides pump controls, valve controls, and automatic overfill protection for storage tanks and transportation containers while transferring cargo to and from this tank farm.  


ISOPENTANE, N-PENTANE, & PENTANE BLEND INTERMODAL TRANSFERS: PROCESS 2

Isopentane, n-Pentane, and Pentane Blends containing a 5 to 95-percent mixture of Isopentane and n-Pentane are periodically transloaded directly between loaded rail tank cars spotted at the Stolthaven Houst

on Terminal's Rail Rack R-2 into empty ISO tank containers located at Truck Rack T-6, with no intermediate product storage in any of the terminal's above-ground storage tanks.  Vapors generated during these intermittent transfer operations are directed to the Tank Farm Vent Flare for emission control.  Loaded pentane rail cars are received into the Stolthaven Houston Terminal, and are held on the facility's rail storage tracks before being moved to Rail Rack R-2 to perform the product transfers into empty ISO Tank Containers that have been pre-purged with Nitrogen and spotted at Truck Rack T-6.  Note that after loading, the ISO Containers are secured, weighed, and immediately shipped off-site by tractor-trailer after the appropriate transportation paperwork is completed.  Maximum chemical inventories reported with this RMP for Isopentane and n-Pentane conservatively assume that 12 rail cars loaded with 31,500-gallons of Isopentane cargo and six rail cars loaded with 31,500-gallons of n-Pentane cargo are held simultaneously on the facility's storage tracks.   Rail cars of the blended Pentane mixture are included in these totals.  During calendar year 2023, 32 separate Isopentane and n-Pentane intermodal transfer events were completed at the Stolthaven Houston Terminal between Racks R-2 and T-6.  Note that all Isopentane, n-Pentane, and Pentane Blend intermodal transfers use the same equipment and transfer spots.  A dedicated transfer line between Rail Rack R-2 and Truck Rack T-6 (the R2-T6-70 Line) is used for all Pentane transloading operations.  Only one Pentane rail car is unloaded at a time.  


P-TANK FARM VINYL ACETATE MONOMER STORAGE AND TRANSFERS: PROCESS 3

Storage Tank P50-5 is an existing IFR tank at the Stolthaven Houston Terminal with a maximum working capacity of 50,445-barrels, which corresponds to a maximum VAM storage capacity of approximately 16.6-million pounds (2,118,691-gallons).  Tank P50-5, which represents the facility's largest volume of VAM

held in a single storage vessel, was placed into VAM service for the first time on February 25, 2010.  VAM is received into this tank via barge delivery using a dedicated marine dock line.  Product is stored and subsequently shipped outbound according to customer requirements via marine parcel tankers, and occasionally by barges, that load at Stolthaven Houston's existing Dock 2/3.  VAM may also be transferred periodically directly from barges into rail tank cars with no intermediate product storage, directly between barges and marine parcel tankers using a shore loop dock line, and VAM slops can also be received into the terminal from marine vessels berthed at Stolthaven Houston's docks.    Vapors generated during all loading operations are controlled by a Vapor Combustor, and a quarterly leak detection and repair ("LDAR") program is applied to find and promptly repair any equipment leaks.  

In 2017 Stolthaven Houston placed IFR Storage Tank P50-4 into VAM service.  Tank P50-4 has a working capacity of 48,651-barrels, which corresponds to a maximum VAM storage capacity of approximately 16-million pounds (2,043,337-gallons).  As a result of the 2017 VAM storage project for Tank P50-4, piping modifications were completed in P-Manifold to connect the marine transfer system for Tank P50-4 into the existing Dock Line P-D3-78, which was already in place for Tank P50-5 and is dedicated exclusively to VAM service.  A new VAM filter-pot was also installed adjacent to Storage Tank P50-4.  

Stolthaven Houston's permanent, stationary fire-water protection systems in the immediate area of Tank P50-5 were also upgraded to provide additional cooling water if-needed in the event of an emergency incident involving any of the facility's flammable or combustible liquid storage tanks in close proximity.  Existing portable water delivery systems also remain available should they be needed in the event of an emergency.  Note that Stolthaven Houston, Inc. has over 14-years' experience

in the safe storage and handling of VAM.  Stolthaven Houston plans to fully automate P-Tank Farm under a capital project that will begin in 2025.   Quick close ball valves equipped with remote actuators were installed on both P-Tank Farm VAM storage tanks when these two tanks were last clean and empty in anticipation of installing full automation controls.


Q-TANK FARM VINYL ACETATE MONOMER STORAGE AND TRANSFERS: PROCESS 4

In November of 2024 Stolthaven Houston plans to place IFR Storage Tank Q30-13 into VAM service for the first time in a newly Covered Process.  Tank Q30-13 has a working capacity of 30,707-barrels, which corresponds to a maximum VAM storage capacity of approximately 10-million pounds (1,289,684-gallons).   Existing Marine Dock Line A6-D3-89, which was already in place for Storage Tank Q30-13, will be dedicated exclusively to VAM service for this new process.   

Stolthaven Houston plans to receive VAM into Tank Q30-13 via inbound marine deliveries from barges and parcel tankers.  The cargo will be stored, and ultimately transferred off-site via trucks loaded at Truck Rack T-4, rail cars loaded at Rail Rack R-3, and barges and ships loaded at Dock 2/3.  Vapors generated during all VAM loading operations will be controlled by a Vapor Combustor, and a quarterly LDAR program will also be applied to find and promptly repair any equipment leaks.   IFR Storage Tank Q30-13 is equipped with an independent high-level alarm in the field, in addition to continuous tank level monitoring in the Stolthaven Houston operations control room.  

The VAM in Tank Q30-13 will be inhibited for quality control reasons.  A third-party surveyor will sample the tank on a monthly basis to verify inhibitor levels, and will add inhibitor as necessary to ensure the tank remains on specification.  After inhibitor is added the tank will be circulated to ensure adequate mixing.  

Tank pump control and end of line valve controls at Dock 2/3 and Truck Rack T-4 are currently automa

ted for Storage Tank Q30-13.  Stolthaven Houston will install a valve that may be operated remotely on the Storage Tank Q30-13 rail system located at Rack R-3 by the end of 2024 to provide for future full automation of rail operations.  Stolthaven Houston plans to fully automate Q-Tank Farm under a capital project that will begin in 2026.   Quick close ball valves that may be equipped with remote actuators were installed at Tank Q30-13 when this tank was previously clean and empty in anticipation of installing full automation controls.  

For the purpose of defining maximum chemical inventories noted in this RMP, the densities of all regulated substances at their lowest expected operating temperatures were chosen to provide conservative estimates for the maximum chemical quantities (in pounds) that may be on-site at one time.  For the Off-Site Consequence Analysis ("OCA") parameters, specifically the vapor pressures for each regulated substance, Stolthaven Houston applied the vapor pressures at maximum expected temperatures to provide the most conservative OCA modeling results.  

   
§ 68.155(c):  ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM

We take a systematic, proactive approach to prevent accidental releases of chemicals at Stolthaven Houston.  Our management systems address each of the key features of successful prevention programs, including:

- Process Safety Information ("PSI")

- Process Hazard Analysis ("PHA")

- ISO 9001:2015 Certified Quality Management System ("QMS") for continuous process improvement

- Employee Training / Local Training Manual 

- Mechanical Integrity

- Spill Containment, Control, and Countermeasures

- Management of Change ("MOC")

- Pre-Startup Safety Review ("PSSR")

- Vapor Control Systems

- Compliance Audits

- Formal Incident Investigation

- Employee Participation Program

- Hot Work / Safe Work Permits

- Departmental / Safety Meetings

- Trained Emergency Response Team ("ERT")

- Emergency / Incident Response Contractors

- Mutu

al Aid Membership

- Ongoing Automation Enhancements and Upgrades

The above-referenced elements of our prevention program work together to help us prevent and respond, as needed, to any accidental chemical releases.  Our company and our employees are committed to the standard these management systems set for the way we conduct business, and we have controls in place to ensure that we meet our own high standards for accident prevention.


§ 68.155(d):  FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY

During the preceding five years there have been no accidental releases from any RMP covered process at the Stolthaven Houston Terminal that resulted in deaths, injuries, significant property damage on site, or known offsite deaths, injuries, evacuations, sheltering-in-place, property damage, or environmental damage. 

All incidents at the Stolthaven Houston Terminal are formally investigated as part of our facility's ISO Certified QMS to identify the root cause of the event, and to implement appropriate corrective actions for continuous process improvement.


§ 68.155(e):  EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM

We maintain an integrated contingency plan, which consolidates the various federal, state, and local regulatory requirements for emergency response planning.  Stolthaven Houston maintains a Facility Response Plan ("FRP") with the United States Coast Guard, Houston-Galveston Sector. Our emergency response program provides the essential planning and training standards for effectively protecting our employees, the public, the environment, and company assets during potential emergency situations.  Furthermore, we coordinate our action plan with the community emergency response plan and the North Channel Area Local Emergency Planning Committee ("LEPC").  Stolthaven Houston's hazardous chemical inventory report (i.e. Tier II report) is maintained current with the Texas Commission on Environmental Quality ("TCEQ"), the North Channel Area LEPC, and the local Channelview, Texas Fire Department.  Stoltha

ven Houston, Inc. is also a member of Channel Industries Mutual Aid ("CIMA"), which can provide world-class, rapid response assistance in the event of an on-site emergency.    

An Emergency Action Plan ("EAP") is maintained which provides guidelines for responding to various emergencies such as fires, hazardous material spills, personnel injuries, severe weather events, and property damage that may occur at the Stolthaven Houston Terminal.   


§ 68.155(f):  CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY

The following is a list of completed and planned/ongoing initiatives at the Stolthaven Houston Terminal to assist in preventing and/or responding to accidental chemical releases, to protect company employees and the environment, and to effectively manage hazards present at the facility:

- As they are made available when empty and clean, cargo tanks are equipped with quick-closing ball valves to replace existing gate valves as part of ongoing safety enhancements and automation efforts, which include status alarms displayed in the terminal's 24-hour Operations Control Room, automated tank overfill protection systems, pump controls, and remotely actuated valve closures.  Complete automation of D-Tank Farm and associated systems has been completed.  Automation of P-Tank Farm and associated systems is planned to commence in 2025.   Automation of Q-Tank Farm and associated systems is planned to commence in 2026.

- Tank Farms A, AE, and BE, while not currently covered by the EPA RMP regulations, are fully automated, as will be new Tank Farms CE and DE, which are under construction and are expected to become operational during the fourth quarter of 2025.  

- Automated end-of-line valves installed at Truck Racks, Rail Racks, and Marine Docks to assist in preventing overfills and possible cargo contaminations.  

- Double verification of all line and hose connections before commencing any product transfer operations to reduce the possibility of incorrect valve and/or hose alignment.

- Added

a concrete secondary containment floor and total organic carbon ("TOC") analyzer to the facility's A-Tank Farm.  A-Tank Farm is one of Stolthaven Houston's original Tank Farms, and was originally constructed with earthen secondary containment.  

- New fire monitor and valve installation in A-Tank Farm that provides 500 to 1000-gallons per minute ("GPM") water flow.  

- Purchased a Ferrara Inferno Super Pumper Fire Truck, which can provide 6,000-GPM of flow; the truck holds 800-gallons of fire-fighting foam and 200-gallons of water.  

- Security camera upgrades improving video coverage at the facility's truck loading racks and piping manifolds.  

- Continuous improvement through the facility's ISO 9001:2015 Certified QMS.

- Employee Experienced Feedback Program.

- Two 753-horsepower fire-water pump driver emergency diesel engines added at Ship Dock 11 for fire-fighting response.  

- Gas detection systems updated to include 5-gas monitors with photo-ionization detectors ("PID").

- Live fire school training at Texas A&M University for Stolthaven Houston ERT members, where they progress from basic training to become advanced fire fighters.  

- Contractor evaluation performed by a third-party service.
